title: Shareable Subentries in Lexonomy as a Solution to the Problem of Multiword Item Placement
segmentation: Good morning, so I'm here to talk about a problem that has been bothering me in lexicography for for a long time, and that is the problem of multi word item placement.

So the problem is that if you have a conventionally structured dictionary where you have dictionary entries and each entry is headed by Edward and the head word is like a single word thing, and then you have multi word phraseological things which you want to describe in your dictionary.
So you're faced with the problem of where do I put them under which Edwards will.
In which entry or should I promote them to the status of headwords and so on?
So this is a problem that keeps coming back again and again in lexicography when dictionaries lived on paper, the problem was there and our diction.
There is mostly live on computer screens, but the problem is still there.

So I just want to what I want to do in my presentation is I want to kind of analyze the problem a little bit and describe some of the solutions that people conventionally usually employ in dictionaries for solving the problem.
And then I'm going to propose my own solution.
And then in the second half of my presentation I want to show you how I have implemented my solution in a dictionary writing system called Laksana Me.
So there's slightly more theoretical part at the beginning, and the more practical part almost like a software demo in the second half of my press.
Station.
So if you have a phraseological multiword item, like third time lucky, there is this perennial question in lexicography that keeps coming back again and again is.
Where do you include this in your dictionary, or does it go under the headword which had?
Where does it come under third or time?
Or lucky, or all of them, or two of them, or neither of them?
Do you perhaps treat treat this as a headwords itself, and so on?
So yeah.
There's there's like 3 typical solutions to this problem.
Solution number one is that you just pick one of these.
You you decide for some reason that you're going to have this phraseological item described under the HEADWORD for 3rd, let's say just say nothing about it underneath the other ones.
Obviously we will probably all agree that that's not ideal becausw, that's not necessarily where the users might be looking for it.

Another another solution solution #2, which is really a variation of solution number one is that you include the item under one of the three possible headwords and then under the other two you just have some sort of a cross reference.
You say third time lucky see under third.
That's a little bit better, but obviously that's not ideal either.
Becausw dictionaries are things that people use while they do something else, so the people post.
Probably people might appreciate having the entire information there on the screen.

Without having to navigate to other entries and finding the location in the target entry where this multi word item is actually described, and so on, and the solution #3 that you often see in born digital dictionaries is that the whole thing is promoted to the status of ahead word.
So you you have a dictionary article in your dictionary and had word is third time lucky.
So strictly speaking it's not ahead word, it's like had multi word, but the terminology is irrelevant.
You have these things at the same level as all the other entries.
That seems like this is the solution to the problem, and people sometimes tell you things like.
Well, this is wonderful because we now have digital dictionaries, so we don't actually have to answer that question.
We can treat this as a headward and we just delegate the responsibility for locating this particular entry to the search algorithm that we have on our dictionary website.
So the end user comes in and the end user searches for, let's say, in the headward time or the string time.
So they are given a list of results and somewhere.
Among the list of results they will have the entry for third time.
Lucky this seems like it's the solution to the problem, but I think it's not becausw.

Because you're delegating the responsibility for showing the entry to the search algorithm, the lexicographer no longer has control over where in the listing of results this particular entry will appear.
Will it be somewhere underneath the end the entry for time?
Will it be somewhere on the right hand side of the screen?
Or maybe the search algorithm is not clever at all?
It's probably will not be listed at all, so you know, as a lexicographer you probably want to have some control over where this item will appear.
If you're including an entry like this under the headword for time, you probably want it to appear under one specific sense of time and not just at the end of the entire entry.
OK, so all the solutions that people conventionally use are not ideal, and I think the ideal answer to the question.
Under which Headward should this be included?
I think the ideal answer is it should be included under all of them becausw.
Because why not?
You know, that's where people might be looking for it.
That's why users might appreciate seeing it, so why not?
Why not all of them?
Why do we have to decide?

So if we want to include a phraseological subentry like this under three different headwords, the only way to do that in a conventional dictionary, including born digital dictionaries, is to just copy and paste.
So we have three separate copies in three separate places, and again, you will probably agree with me that that's not ideal, because that's an invitation for inconsistency.
If six months later, one of your lexicographers goes in and adds a usage example to the entry for third time, lucky under the headword.
Third, there is no implicit automated way to make sure that the same changes also made under the other head words.
OK, so just keeping several copies of what essentially is the same thing in several different places is not great either.
So that's not a solution either.
So why is this a problem?
The problem is that the dictionaries that we write, the dictionary articles that we write, our tree structures.

We obviously dictionary articles originated on paper, then they kind of migrated to computer screens to dictionary writing systems and we started modeling dictionary entries or encoding dictionary entries in XML.
XML is a great markup language for documents and things that kind of look like documents and every dictionary entry is kind of like a small document, but it's it's a tree.
OK, so it it's a tree, doesn't allow you to have.
One item appear in two separate places.
You can always only have a phraseological subentry, which has only one parent.
OK, so XML or a tree XML is a tree structure, which means every element has.
Only one parent and a certain number of child elements.
So for example, a phraseological subentry has only one sense parent.
It cannot have more than two.
OK, that is the problem.

That's that's what is preventing us from including third time lucky under third antimon lucky while just having one sub entry for these things and not actually keeping separate copies in separate places.
So how do we fix this?
One solution that you sometimes come across?
In literature and in sort of experimental dictionaries is that we migrate from trees to graphs.
Becausw graphs are kind of multi dimensional structures where elements can have more, can have different kinds of relations to other elements.
In XML you only have the relation between parent and child and every child can have up to one parent.
But in a graph you can have lots of different relations with lots of different semantics not not only parent child but but all sorts of different things.

So just migrating dictionaries from trees to graphs would seem like a good solution to the problem, But the problem with graphs is that they are probably way too complicated for for for humans to kind of mentally grasp in their heads.
If you look at the two dimensional tree structure that we have in XML, it's easy to show it on a screen and what you're looking at on your screen you you're kind of your XML tree.
That that's what you're looking at is the entire story.
There is nothing else.
OK, you don't have to manipulate a complicated multi dimensional data structure in your head.
You what you see is what you have there.
So trees are kind of very intuitively easy for humans to work with.
Far as graphs are kind of hugely overcomplicated and we don't really have very good user interfaces for editing graphs and just people.
That's probably the reason why graphs haven't really taken off.
As a as an encoding kind of formalism for dictionaries that most of the dictionaries that people write today are trees encoded in XML, so I wanted to solve the problem in a clever way.
So instead of just keeping separate copies of a phraseological subentry in in three separate entries, I.

Assaulted me, maybe we could find some sort of a compromise solution between trees and graphs so that you know instead of having two 2 copies of what I think is the same thing, just having one and having it kind of linked into the the XML tree where where it should appear.
So what I'm proposing is not that we migrate from trees to graphs, but that we kind of augment our trees a little bit so they begin resembling graphs a little bit.
So all our dictionary entries will continue to be trees, but every now and then certain elements will be allowed to have more than one parent.
That's the only change I'm suggesting.
OK, we still have trees.
The only the only changes that elements are allowed to have more than one parent, and so that will kind of conclude the theoretical path.
This is what I'm suggesting is a solution to the problem of multiword item placement and.
In the second half of my presentation, I'm going to show you how I implemented exactly this in in a dictionary writing system called laksana Me like Sonamy is.
It's a dictionary writing system.
You might have heard of it.
You might have not.
It's been it's relatively new.
It's it's only been in the world for like one or maybe two years.
And I mean, this presentation is not an introduction to look salami, but becausw there may be people here who haven't heard of it yet.
I will make.
I will do a very very brief introduction to looks on me now and then I will return to my topic and show you how I implemented the the feature for.

You can create a new dictionary and so on.

You click on things.
You can edit text, you can add elements, remove elements you things like that.
It's a commit, so it's a.
It's an XML editor.
OK, you may have seen one before in other contexts, and you have your list of head words, and you can create entries and so on.
In Lex Onomy you can design the structure of the entries yourself, so you can.

You can decide what your XML elements are going to be called, how they are going to be allowed to stack inside each other, whether you're going to have definitions inside senses or North, and what they're going to be called, and so on.
This is this.
Screen where you kind of design your XML schema.
So this is telling me that each entry begins with A tag called entry.
Then it has something called Headword group underneath each you know.

So there's a whole structure of XML that you can kind of design here, and this will then sort of appear in your XML editor here and in addition to that likes anime is not just a system for writing dictionaries, it's a system for publishing dictionaries as well.
So you can just click a few buttons and.
You you will sort of like salami will allow you to publish your dictionary in there kind of a micro site within the Exonomy website.
So this this is about the home page of your dictionary will look like roughly, you know there's a search box and things like that and the user can type things in and.
You can present your entries to the world relatively easily, just a few clicks.
OK, so this is a very short introduction to laksana me.
Now I'm going to return to my topic and show you how I implemented the share ability shareable subentries feature.
So let's say I have a dictionary.
OK, let's say I have a dictionary which is very simple.
I have entries and inside the entries I have sensors and and inside the senses I have.
Something called fazem.
So I've decided to call this element phrase Eames, and this will include my multi word phrases.
Logical items.
OK, now I'm going to tell axoneme that I want friend seems to be shareable, which means that the Frazee malament will be allowed to have more than one parent in more than one entry.
This is how I do it.
There's a special configuration screen in laksana me where I tell exonomy which elements are going to be allowed to have more than one parent.
So here I'm telling like Sonamy Frazey is going to be allowed to have more than one parent, and then when I go.
Going to edit my entries, you can see that the frazey Malament has a kind of an icon next to it and there's the.
And there's the number 2, isn't it?

And this is telling me that this regime element is included in this entry, and in two other entries somewhere else in my dictionary, if I click on this, it's telling me which those two other entries are and what this means is that if I make any change at all to the sub entry here, that change will automatically be propagated to the other entries where this sub entry occurs.
OK, so that's that's the meaning of this little icon.
If.
I want to add an you phraseological subentry to some location in my entry.
There is an item on.
The menu here which which offers me to find sub entries so I can click on that and I will get a list.
In which I can search for sub entries that exist somewhere else in my dictionary already.
So if I'm working on the entry for time and I suspect that possibly somewhere else in my dictionary, there's a sub entry for third time.
Lucky and I want to include it here.

I can find it in this window and sort of included in the entry, and it's not a copy, it's just a link to the sub entry that already exist somewhere else, or if the subentry I'm looking for is not in my dictionary app, then I can simply click the new button here in the right hand corner, top right hand corner.
Anna.

It will just create an empty phraseological subentry, and I can just fill it in and when I save it, it will kind of be saved in the dictionary and it would be available, potentially for linking from other countries as well.

What else, right?

What we do, what we have in the dictionary now is, we have the entries and then we have the sub entries and the sub entries kind of have acquired sort of independent semi independent existence because they're kind of their items in their own right.

You can even create new ones which will not be linked to any particular entry at you.

Can any changes you make here will automatically be reflected in the entries where these sub entries occur and you can even do things like you can prepare your phraseological subentries before hand somewhere else and then upload a huge corpus of them and have them here and then kind of link them to your entries as you go along.
